channel.title: 8th grade force&motion
channel.description:
omg help please:( also what do you think about taking IPC freshman year then bilogy 2nd year? and what other science classes should i take
RETEACH: Chapter 3 (Section 1) 1. Describe how we know an object is in motion.
2. How can the potential energy of a boulder resting on a hillside be converted into kinetic energy?
3. Your friend kicks a soccer ball toward you, but the ball stops before it reaches you. Your friend says that Newton's first law must be wrong because the ball should have kept moving at a constant speed. How would you explain to your friend that the ball stopping demonstrates that Newton's first law is correct?
4. How does Newton's second law explain why it is easier to push a bicycle to give it a certain acceleration than to push a car to give it the same acceleration?
5. Suppose you are standing on a skateboard or on in-line skates and you toss a backpack full of heavy books toward your friend. What do you think will happen to you, and why? Explain your answer in terms of Newton's third law of motion.

item.title: 8th grade force&motion
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

  1. you technically don’t; read pault’s posts.
  2. assuming the potential energy is gravitational, then the transformation can occur by it being pushed off of the cliff.
  3. objects have a tendency to stay in the same state of motion. the soccer ball, as accordingly, has this tendency; however, the gravitational force, and, as a result, rolling friction (the ball is pulled towards the ground, causing the rubbing and continuous deformation of the ball which results in loss of energy), are outside forces that hinder the motion of the ball.
  4. a = F/m; the mass is inversely proportional to the acceleration, and, obviously, a car has more mass than a bicycle, so reaching a certain acceleration, and, as follows, a certain speed, with a car requires more effort than with a bicycle.
  5. forces come in pairs of action and reaction forces. in this case, the action force is to push the backpack. when doing so, however, the backpack exerts an equal and opposite force (F[sub]1[/sub] = -F[sub]2[/sub]) on you. normally, nothing would happen due to the friction with the ground; however, using a skateboard or pair of skates (glorified wheel-and-axle), the force is pushed over a longer distance, and rolling friction is also less than the normal friction - thus, you can actually notice the reaction force, and, therefore, roll backwards.

Read full topic

item.title: 8th grade force&motion
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

uhh friction is the more valid answer

Both gravity and friction are forces which thwart the motion of the soccer ball, so gravity could be part of a valid answer as well as friction. The question asks us to explain how Newtons first law is proved by the failure of the ball to keep moving. The ball would have continued forever until it hit the observer in the face and fucked his shit up, according to the first part of the law however the forces which hindered the balls movement (gravity, etc…) were greater than the balls inertia so the ball stopped; according to the second part of the law. In this case, the person kicking the ball should work out more and then instead of asking questions he could hit people in the face with his balls, besides he’s an imaginary character and doesn’t even have the right to engage in the Socratic method anyway.

1. the position is changing over time--precisely-correct answer

That is a tautology, it doesn’t describe how you know the object is in motion. You have in fact described motion more fully than necessary without describing your method for knowing that motions is a quality of the object in question. One can have motion without applying the concept of location, and time is not the only way to quantify motion. To correctly answer the question, which asks how we know, not what we know, we must qualify the method of how we achieved the knowledge of the objects motion, which was accomplished through empirical reasoning.

Read full topic

item.title: 8th grade force&motion
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

  1. the position is changing over time–precisely-correct answer
  2. it begins to roll down (kinetic energy is the energy of motion)
  3. friction (not gravity, dumb fucks); objects in motion remain in motion and objects at rest remain at rest unless acted upon by an outside force (friction, in this case)
  4. his second law states that an object’s acceleration increases with increased force and decreases with increased mass (NOTE: mass != weight)
  5. you will roll backwards; third law states every action has an equal and opposite reaction

p.s. take physics. most fun shit evAR

Read full topic

item.title: 8th grade force&motion
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

There is no guarantee that our senses will give us accurate information or that they are even representing to our consciousness anything which remotely resembles the “Objective reality”. In empirical reasoning we trust that which can be quantified and verified by our senses without worrying too much about the solipsistic aspect of our philosophy. However I don’t believe that we can truly “Know” that an object exists in an ontological sense; we can’t verify its’ objective existence. This is the dreamlike quality of reality; we exist in a self created world of sensation. We, the dreamers, create the reality we live in.

Strange, indeed, that you should not have suspected that your universe and its contents were only dreams, visions, fiction! Strange, because they are so frankly and hysterically insane - like all dreams...

Read full topic

item.title: 8th grade force&motion
item.dc:creator: @davidude36 Brolapse
item.description:
@davidude36 wrote:

1 it is moving? Fuck knows, seems pretty stupid question.

2 potential energy can be converted into kinetic energy by allowing it to move downwards, so pushing it off the hill side would work.

3 gravity etc

4 force = mass x acceleration. The car has a much greater mass than the bicycle, so to make it accelerate you have to use a fuckton more force

5 Newtons Third Law: “To every action there is an equal and opposite reaction.” Therefore you throwing a bag left would cause you to move right etc

RETEACH: Chapter 3 (Section 1)

  1. Describe how we know an object is in motion.

  2. How can the potential energy of a boulder resting on a hillside be converted into kinetic energy?

  3. Your friend kicks a soccer ball toward you, but the ball stops before it reaches you. Your friend says

  4. How does Newton’s second law explain why it is easier to push a bicycle to give it a certain

  5. Suppose you are standing on a skateboard or on in-line skates and you toss a backpack full of heavy
    books toward your friend. What do you think will happen to you, and why? Explain your answer in
